Musk has praised China and has been described as having a close relationship with the Chinese government, allowing access to its markets for Tesla.[409] After Gigafactory Shanghai produced its first batch of vehicles, Musk thanked the Chinese government and Chinese people while criticizing the United States and its people.[410]: 207–208 In 2022, Musk wrote an article for *China Cyberspace*, the official publication of Cyberspace Administration of China, which enforces Internet censorship in China. 
</fragment>
<fragment>

Musk condemned COVID-19 lockdowns and initially refused to close the Tesla Fremont Factory in March 2020, defying the local shelter-in-place order.[427][435][436] In May 2020, he reopened the Tesla factory, defying the local stay-at-home order,[437][438] and warned workers that they would be unpaid, and their unemployment benefits might be jeopardized, if they did not report to work.[438] In December 2022, Musk called for prosecution of former National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases director Anthony Fauci.[439][440]

Tesla's stock market value sank by over $100 billion the next day in reaction to the deal.[222][223] He subsequently tweeted criticism of Twitter executive Vijaya Gadde's policies to his 86 million followers, which led to some of them engaging in sexist and racist harassment against her.[224] Exactly a month after announcing the takeover, Musk stated that the deal was "on hold" following a report that 5% of Twitter's daily active users were spam accounts.[225] Although he initially affirmed his commitment to the acquisition,[226] he sent notification of his termination of the deal in July; Twitter's Board of Directors responded that they were committed to holding him to the transaction.[227] On July 12, 2022, Twitter formally sued Musk in the Chancery Court of Delaware for breaching a legally binding agreement to purchase Twitter.[228] In October 2022, Musk reversed again, offering to purchase Twitter at $54.20 per share.[229] The acquisition was officially completed on October 27.[230]

In 2016, Musk co-founded Neuralink, a neurotechnology startup company, with an investment of $100 million.[184][185] Neuralink aims to integrate the human brain with artificial intelligence (AI) by creating devices that are embedded in the brain to facilitate its merging with machines. Such technology could enhance memory or allow the devices to communicate with software.[185][186] The company also hopes to develop devices with which to treat neurological conditions such as Alzheimer's disease, dementia, and spinal cord injuries.[187]

Immediately after the acquisition, Musk fired several top Twitter executives including CEO Parag Agrawal;[230][231] Musk became the CEO instead.[232] He instituted a $7.99 monthly subscription for a "blue check",[233][234][19] and laid off a significant portion of the company's staff.[235][236] Musk lessened content moderation, including reinstating accounts like the *Bee*,[237][238] and in December, Musk released internal documents relating to Twitter's moderation of Hunter Biden's laptop controversy in the leadup to the 2020 presidential election.[239]


Comments on these internal documents by journalists, Matt Taibbi, Bari Weiss, Michael Shellenberger and others were posted at Twitter as the Twitter Files. The United States House Committee on the Judiciary held hearings on the Twitter Files on March 9, 2023 at which Taibbi and Shellenberger gave testimony. [240]

### Accusations of antisemitism[edit]


The Israel government and several media outlets accused Musk of antisemitism due to him spreading George Soros conspiracy theories,[353] although some Israeli officials defended Musk.[354] A tweet of his in November 2023 supported white nationalist ideology[355] and affirmed another antisemitic conspiracy theory that Jews push "hatred against Whites."[356][357] The following day, Musk made a tweet supporting white pride.[358][359] Advertisers distanced themselves from his tweets.[360] Musk wrote that he doesn’t believe that "all Jewish communities" hate white people, but specifically took aim at the Anti-Defamation League.[361]

Working towards its goal of reusable rockets, in 2015 SpaceX successfully landed the first stage of a Falcon 9 on an inland platform.[104] Later landings were achieved on autonomous spaceport drone ships, an ocean-based recovery platform.[105] In 2018, SpaceX launched the Falcon Heavy; the inaugural mission carried Musk's personal Tesla Roadster as a dummy payload.[106][107] Since 2019,[108] SpaceX has been developing Starship, a fully-reusable, super-heavy-lift launch vehicle intended to replace the Falcon 9 and the Falcon Heavy.[109] In 2020, SpaceX launched its first crewed flight, the Demo-2, becoming the first private company to place astronauts into orbit and dock a crewed spacecraft with the ISS.[110]

In 1995, Musk, his brother Kimbal, and Greg Kouri founded Global Link, later renamed to Zip2.[67][68] The company was financed mainly through a financing round of US$200,000, of which 10% was contributed by his father Errol Musk.[69] The company developed an Internet city guide with maps, directions, and yellow pages, and marketed it to newspapers.[70] They worked at a small rented office in Palo Alto,[71] with Musk coding the website every night.[71] Eventually, Zip2 obtained contracts with *The New York Times* and the *Chicago Tribune*.[61] The brothers persuaded the board of directors to abandon a merger with CitySearch;[72] however, Musk's attempts to become CEO were thwarted.[73] Compaq acquired Zip2 for $307 million in cash in February 1999,[74][75] and Musk received $22 million for his 7-percent share.[76]

His writing the article was described as conflicting with his advocacy for free speech.[411][412] Musk later advocated for Taiwan to become a "special administrative zone" of China which drew cross-party criticism from Taiwanese lawmakers.[413][414][415] In October 2022, Musk posted a Twitter poll and "peace plan" to resolve the Russian invasion of Ukraine.[416][417] It was reported that Musk allegedly spoke with Russian President Vladimir Putin prior to the proposal, which Musk denied.[418][419][420] Musk has repeatedly expressed concern that a protracted war between Russia and Ukraine could lead to the use of nuclear weapons and the outbreak of World War III.[421][422][423] In October 2023, Musk said that "We are sleepwalking our way into World War III with one foolish decision after the other."[424]

Many of us worked tirelessly for him for years and were tossed to the curb like a piece of litter without a second thought. Maybe it was calculated to keep the rest of the workforce on their toes and scared; maybe he was just able to detach from human connection to a remarkable degree. What was clear is that people who worked for him were like ammunition: used for a specific purpose until exhausted and discarded."

The CEO is known for outsized claims and ambitious goals. But numerous factory workers say he doesn't follow through – and that his leadership sets a troubling tone.

![Two green vans sporting the SolarCity logo](image)SolarCity solar-panel installation vans in 2009
Musk provided the initial concept and financial capital for SolarCity, which his cousins Lyndon and Peter Rive founded in 2006.[173] By 2013, SolarCity was the second largest provider of solar power systems in the United States.[174] In 2014, Musk promoted the idea of SolarCity building an advanced production facility in Buffalo, New York, triple the size of the largest solar plant in the United States.[175] Construction of the factory started in 2014 and was completed in 2017. It operated as a joint venture with Panasonic until early 2020.[176][177]


</fragment>
<fragment>

Musk's handling of employees—whom he communicates with directly through mass emails—has been characterized as "carrot and stick", rewarding those "who offer constructive criticism" while also being known to impulsively threaten, swear at, and fire his employees.[248][249][250] Musk said he expects his employees to work for long hours, sometimes for 80 hours per week.[251] He has his new employees sign strict non-disclosure agreements and often fires in sprees,[252][253] such as during the Model 3 "production hell" in 2018.[253] In 2022, Musk revealed plans to fire 10 percent of Tesla's workforce, due to his concerns about the economy.[254] That same month, he suspended remote work at SpaceX and Tesla and threatened to fire employees who do not work 40 hours per week in the office.[255]


</fragment>

Musk has described climate change as the greatest threat to humanity after AI,[371] and has advocated for a carbon tax.[372] Musk was a critic of President Donald Trump's stance on climate change,[373][374] and resigned from two presidential business advisory councils following Trump's 2017 decision to withdraw the United States from the Paris Agreement.[375]


</fragment>
<fragment>

In a YouTube podcast interview on November 10, 2023, Musk criticized Israel's actions in the Gaza Strip during the 2023 Israel–Hamas war, saying that Hamas "wanted to commit the worst atrocities that they could in order to provoke the most aggressive response possible from Israel." He added that "if you kill somebody’s child in Gaza, you have made at least a few Hamas members who will die just to kill an Israeli."[425] On November 17, 2023, Musk announced a policy change on the X platform, stating that users who use terms like "decolonization" and "from the river to the sea," or similar expressions that imply genocide of the Jewish people in Israel, will be suspended.[426]

In July 2018, Musk arranged for his employees to build a mini-submarine to assist the rescue of children trapped in a flooded cavern in Thailand.[288] Richard Stanton, leader of the international rescue diving team, urged Musk to facilitate the construction of the vehicle as a back-up, in case flooding worsened.[289] Engineers at SpaceX and the Boring Company built the mini-submarine from a Falcon 9 liquid oxygen transfer tube in eight hours and personally delivered it to Thailand.[290][291] By this time, however, eight of the 12 children, had already been rescued, the rescuers employing full face masks, oxygen, and anesthesia; consequently, Thai authorities declined to use the submarine.[288] In March 2019, Musk was later one of the 187 people who received various honors conferred by the King of Thailand for involvement in the rescue effort.[292]

In 2000, X.com merged with online bank Confinity to avoid competition,[71][79][80] as the latter's money-transfer service PayPal was more popular than X.com's service.[81] Musk then returned as CEO of the merged company. His preference for Microsoft over Unix-based software caused a rift among the company's employees, and eventually led Confinity co-founder Peter Thiel to resign.[82] With the company suffering from compounding technological issues and the lack of a cohesive business model, the board ousted Musk and replaced him with Thiel in September 2000.[83][b] Under Thiel, the company focused on the money-transfer service and was renamed PayPal in 2001.[85][86]

In 2019, Musk announced work on a device akin to a sewing machine that could embed threads into a human brain.[184] He is listed as the sole author of an October 2019 paper that details some of Neuralink's research,[188] although Musk's being listed as such rankled the Neuralink team's researchers.[189] At a 2020 live demonstration, Musk described one of their early devices as "a Fitbit in your skull" that could soon cure paralysis, deafness, blindness, and other disabilities. Many neuroscientists and publications criticized these claims,[190][191][192] with *MIT Technology Review* describing them as "highly speculative" and "neuroscience theater".[190] During the demonstration, Musk revealed a pig with a Neuralink implant that tracked neural activity related to smell.[187] In 2022, Neuralink announced that clinical trials would begin by the end of the year.[193]

SpaceX attempted its first launch of the Falcon 1 rocket in 2006.[97] Though the rocket failed to reach Earth orbit, it was awarded a Commercial Orbital Transportation Services program contract from NASA Administrator (and former SpaceX consultant[98]) Mike Griffin later that year.[99][100] After two more failed attempts that nearly caused Musk and his companies to go bankrupt,[97] SpaceX succeeded in launching the Falcon 1 into orbit in 2008.[101] Later that year, SpaceX received a $1.6 billion Commercial Resupply Services contract from NASA for 12 flights of its Falcon 9 rocket and Dragon spacecraft to the International Space Station, replacing the Space Shuttle after its 2011 retirement.[102] In 2012, the Dragon vehicle docked with the ISS, a first for a commercial spacecraft.[103]

Musk said that the U.S. government should not provide subsidies to companies, but impose a carbon tax to discourage poor behavior.[450][451] The free market, in his view, would achieve the best solution, and producing environmentally unfriendly vehicles should have consequences.[452] Tesla has received billions of dollars in subsidies.[453] In addition, Tesla made large sums from government-initiated systems of zero-emissions credits offered in California and at the United States federal level, which facilitated initial consumer adoption of Tesla vehicles, as the tax credits given by governments enabled Tesla's battery electric vehicles to be price-competitive, in comparison with existing lower-priced internal combustion engine vehicles.[454] Notably, Tesla generates some of its revenue from its sales of carbon credits granted to the company, by both the European Union Emissions Trading System and the Chinese national carbon trading scheme.[455][456][457][458]

msg.content: Bill Gates attended Harvard University but dropped out to focus on Microsoft.</s>
Jeff Bezos attended Princeton University, where he graduated with a Bachelor of Science in Engineering (BSE) in electrical engineering and computer science in 1986.</s>
Larry Ellison attended the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign and the University of Chicago, but he did not complete his degree at either institution.</s>
Mark Zuckerberg attended Harvard University, where he launched Facebook in February 2004 with his roommates Eduardo Saverin, Andrew McCollum, Dustin Moskovitz, and Chris Hughes.</s>

Elon Musk attended the University of Pretoria before immigrating to Canada at age 18, acquiring citizenship through his Canadian-born mother. He matriculated at Queen's University in Ontario, Canada, and later transferred to the University of Pennsylvania (UPenn), where he completed studies for a Bachelor of Arts degree in physics and a Bachelor of Science degree in economics from the Wharton School. Musk also attended Stanford University briefly before dropping out to focus on his entrepreneurial ventures.</s>
